questions.question: How committed am I to my objectives?

answers.reply: If you're very committed, then you must prepare accordingly and ensure that your companions are on the same wavelength. Remember - being very committed is not the same as taking high risks! Do not take unnecessary risks. It's better to stay alive even without having achieved your objective than to die trying.
Be aware that it's OK to back down if the avalanche conditions indicate that you should. Being committed does not mean dying because you ignored the conditions.

Do your companions feel this way? Will they push you to do things you don't want to do? Should you go if you are not really committed? Ask yourself why you are going, and don't go if avalanche conditions are not favorable or you don't feel comfortable.

questions.question: Do I know what level of risk my companions are willing to take?

answers.reply: Great! You're all on the same wavelength. However, if you are all willing to take high risks, who will be the voice of reason if avalanche conditions are bad? Remember, high risk encourages poor decision making. What does this mean for your preparations and planning? It's important that you begin to plan a route that satisfies everyone.

Uh-oh. This is a problem. Do you really want to go with them? If yes, what does this mean for the safety of the team? Are you sure you want to take more risks than you are comfortable with? You have only three options now:
    * Don't go.
    * Try convincing your companions that it's not worth the risk.
    * Adjust your risk level to theirs.

Always ask yourself: "Am I willing to die while taking this risk?"

This means that your team will have trouble in the field as everyone has different expectations. What does this mean for the safety of the team? Are you willing to put their lives at risk? Will you push them into areas they are not comfortable in? If so, are you willing to take responsibility for their deaths?

answers.text: No, I have no idea what level of risk they are willing to take.
answers.reply: This is not good. Your group should talk about this before you decide to go on this trip together. Plan a time and place to chat about this with your companions so that you can all understand each others risk propensity.

questions.question: Will they travel to areas that would raise the hair on the back of my neck?

answers.reply: Good. This means you are OK traveling with them. What does this mean for your preparations and planning?

This is not good. This means that you are likely to be placed in situations that make you very uncomfortable. Ask yourself: "Do I want to go with them? Why? What does this mean for the safety of the team? What does this mean for preparations and planning?"
This is trouble. If you have no idea, then you need to talk to your companions. Spend some time talking this through to ensure that everyone knows what to expect on the trip.

questions.question: Are they willing to put me at risk as well?

answers.reply: Good! Are you sure? What does this mean in terms of how you will work together?
Do you really want to travel with them? Why are you going with them if they are willing to risk your life?

questions.question: Do my companions have the necessary equipment for avalanche rescue?

answers.reply: You should review the equipment checklist. The right equipment is essential for rescue during an avalanche.

This is not good. Remember - the right equipment is essential for rescue during an avalanche. If they don't have the equipment, how will they be able to rescue you? The proper equipment is critical in a survival situation. Ask yourself: "Do I want to go with them?" If yes, where can they get the necessary equipment?
Great! Be sure they know how to use it. Now, what does this mean for your preparations and planning?

questions.question: Do they know how to use it?

answers.reply: Ask them. Make sure they do know how to use the equipment. Remember, your life is in their hands.
Big problem! How will they rescue you if you are buried in an avalanche? Are you sure you want to go with them? If so, where can they learn how to use the equipment?
Great! Be sure to test all the gear before you head out.

questions.question: Do my companions know what to do in the backcountry?

answers.reply: If you're not sure, talk to your group about their skills and abilities.

This could pose a big problem for you in the field. What would you do if something were to happen? Are you sure you want to go with them? If so, how will this affect the trip? Should you choose less challenging terrain until they get more experience?
Great! Does this impact your preparations and planning?

questions.question: Are they experienced?

answers.reply: Talk to your companions. Determine how many trips they've taken, where they've gone, and how many years they've been traveling in the backcountry. This will help you decide if you really want to go with them.
Do you still want to go with them? How will this affect your trip? Should you choose less challenging terrain until they get some more experience?
Great! This will help you ensure that your companions know how to travel in the backcountry.

questions.question: Are they fit enough?

answers.reply: Talk to the group! Determine if you should choose less challenging terrain until they get into shape.
Do you still want to go with them? How will this affect your trip? Should you choose less challenging terrain until they are more in shape?
Great! This means that they will be solid companions in the backcountry. What does this mean for your preparations and planning?

questions.question: If something happened, like a blizzard, would they know what to do?

answers.reply: Talk to your group about their skills and abilities.
This could pose a big problem for you in the field. Imagine spending a night out there! What could happen? Are you sure you want to go with them? What can you do to help them prepare?
Great! Does this impact your preparations and planning?

questions.question: Do they have experience traveling in the terrain I’ve chosen for the trip?

answers.reply: Talk to the group! Check whether they have any experience traveling in the terrain you've chosen.
That's OK, as long as you do some solid planning!
Great! Talk to them and see if they have any tips about traveling through the area.

questions.question: Does everyone feel comfortable with the choice of route given the avalanche conditions?

answers.reply: Great! You and your companions have done a good job choosing the right route.

This spells trouble. It could mean that you are being forced into a situation that threatens your life, or that you are threatening the lives of others. Either way, you might end up making very bad decisions. It's time to reassess and determine if you should choose a different route.

questions.question: Does the difficulty of the route match the skills and abilities of the entire group?

answers.reply: Great! You should have a fun time.
What if something happens? Don't go!

questions.question: Are there other hazards that affect the route (e.g. creek crossings, rock fall, etc.)?

answers.reply: Talk to your group and be sure you know enough about route-finding and safe travel. Be sure you manage the hazards effectively!
Good. Then your biggest worry will still be avalanches.

questions.question: What are anticipated travel times to and from objectives? Could this affect exposure to hazards as hazards can change throughout the day?

answers.text: I haven’t even thought about this.....
answers.reply: Travel times are very important when dealing with hazards. For example, you might pass a hazard safely in the morning but, because of weather changes or other factors, it becomes unsafe later in the day upon your return.

answers.text: I’ve thought about this and feel that the hazards will not change.
answers.reply: This is rare! For things to remain stable, you need a perfectly stable day - no wind, no changes in temperatures, etc.

questions.question: Is there a point of no return?

answers.text: I’m not sure what “point of no return” means
answers.reply: That's OK. "Point of no return" refers to a situation in which you are so far out in the backcountry that it would be nearly impossible for you to return to your base/vehicle safely. This is not good. It means you must be prepared to spend a night in the backcountry.

answers.text: Yes, there is a point of no return.
answers.reply: OK. Just make sure you are well prepared to spend a night in the backcountry.

answers.text: No, we plan on to return before we are too far in.
answers.reply: Great! But it wouldn't hurt to be prepared - just in case.

questions.question: Are there practical alternate routes, escape routes, and turn-around locations?

answers.reply: That's OK, but you need to spend more time planning your route.
Good! This is important if something were to happen to your existing route. You don't want to get trapped with no escape, so plan accordingly.

What if something happens on your planned route? You'll be in trouble, and you might take risks that are way beyond your comfort zone or else end up spending a night in the backcountry. Seriously evaluate whether you want to take this route or choose an alternative with escape routes and turn-around locations.

questions.question: If something goes wrong, do you know how to get out safely?

answers.reply: Great! You and your companions have done a good job choosing the right route.

This spells trouble. It could mean that you are being forced into a situation that threatens your life, or that you are threatening the lives of others. Either way, you might end up making very bad decisions. It's time to reassess and determine if you should choose a different route.
